awd_abstract_narration:
Optical tweezers won the 2018 Nobel Prize in physics for their applications in biological systems. The tweezers use a highly focused laser beam to trap and manipulate small objects, including cells, particles, bacteria, and virus. Despite the huge success of optical tweezers, the requirement of sophisticated optical setups and high working power prevent their non-invasive manipulation of fragile objects. Tremendous efforts have been made to develop new techniques for optical trapping. However, a universal strategy to safely manipulate different particles and cells in various liquid environments is still elusive. This proposal aims to develop a new optical tweezing platform based on laser cooling and thermal migration of particles in a temperature gradient. Laser cooling can create a localized cold spot on a substrate where various particles can be trapped by thermophoresis. The cooling-induced trapping is expected to effectively avoid the thermal damages due to optical heating in conventional optical tweezer, and the general thermophoretic migration behavior allows this strategy to be used for a wide range of biological cells and nanoparticles to advance life sciences and biomedical applications, including tissue engineering, cellular biology, early disease diagnosis, and drug delivery. The proposed research at the interfaces of physics, photonics, thermo-fluidics, colloidal sciences, and biology will provide interdisciplinary research opportunities for graduate students, undergraduate students, and K-12 students. The outreach efforts will be integrated into two existing Women in Engineering Program initiatives on campus to increase recruiting women and underrepresented minorities into engineering. 

Opto-thermophoretic tweezers were recently developed as an alternative strategy to manipulate particles and cells in a light-controlled temperature gradient with simple optics and low operation power. However, the current laser-heating-based opto-thermophoretic tweezers suffer from limited applicability to special solvent conditions and potential optothermal damages. The objective of this proposal is to develop and apply new opto-thermophoretic tweezers based on laser cooling of the substrates. Due to the common thermophobia in colloidal species, a variety of biological cells and particles can be trapped at the laser beams via thermophoresis in their native environments. In addition, this design can avoid thermal damages due to the temperature increase in optical tweezers and the heating-based opto-thermophoretic tweezers. The proposed research will provide a novel platform for versatile and non-invasive optical manipulation for nanoparticles and biological cells. The intellectual merit is that the proposed research will improve fundamental understanding of laser cooling and thermophoresis, establish safe optical manipulation techniques for cells in biological media, and advance biological applications of optical tweezers, including studies of cell-cell interactions and thermal cues in cellular behaviors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Traditional optical tweezers rely on high laser power and refractive index contrast, often causing thermal and photon damage to trapped objects like biological cells and nanoparticles. While optothermal tweezers offer reduced laser power requirements, they remain limited by medium constraints and excessive laser heating. To address these challenges, the NSF-funded project on Laser-Cooling-Driven Opto-Thermophoretic Tweezers (LCOTTs) aimed to enhance precision, versatility, and biocompatibility in optical manipulation, contributing significantly to advancements in the laser manipulation field. Key goals included investigating the transport of colloidal particles in laser-cooling-induced temperature gradients, developing LCOTTs for thermophoretic trapping, and demonstrating dynamic manipulation of cells in biological media.
Progress and Key Achievements
2020-2021: Foundational Research and Platform Development
During the first year, foundational work established principles of laser-cooling-driven optothermal manipulation. The team developed LCOTTs using Ytterbium-doped Yttrium Lithium Fluoride substrates, achieving multimodal manipulation, including out-of-plane rotation of micro-objects. These advancements laid the groundwork for the integration of thermophoretic effects with laser cooling, reducing power requirements and improving trapping precision.
2021-2022: Expanded Capabilities with Optothermoelectric Tweezers
Building on initial progress, the project demonstrated the potential of optothermoelectric tweezers by integrating polyethylene glycol (PEG) and phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) solutions with functionalized substrates. This system harnessed synergistic light-induced depletion forces, thermoelectric effects, and electrokinetic forces to achieve safe and effective manipulation of nano- and micro-particles. Notably, yeast cells were manipulated through safe tweeze-and-roll operations, demonstrating biocompatibility and utility for biomedical research.
2022-2023: Breakthroughs in Three-Dimensional Manipulation
The project achieved significant advancements in three-dimensional manipulation of plasmonic vesicles using Hypothermal Opto-Thermophoretic Tweezers (HOTTs). This approach enabled controlled cargo release for potential drug delivery applications while minimizing thermal damage and power usage. Additionally, the team developed a multimodal manipulation system for navigating rough biological surfaces, overcoming substrate limitations.
A novel single-cell rotation-based method was introduced for high-resolution, label-free quantification of subcellular binding kinetics, enhancing understanding of cell adhesion dynamics. These developments underscored the versatility of optothermal techniques for biomedical and biophysical applications.
2023-2024: Advanced Applications and Multicellular Organism Manipulation
The final year of the project focused on expanding the scope of LCOTTs to address more complex scientific challenges:
  1. Thermophoretic Behavior in Coacervate Droplets
    The team explored thermophoretic behaviors in heat-dissociative coacervate droplets, uncovering how temperature gradients drive molecular redistribution and interfacial tension variations. These findings provided insights into prebiotic molecular organization, contributing to the understanding of the origins of life.
  2. Microrobotic Swarms with Adaptive Navigation
    Adaptive algorithms were developed to enhance responsiveness and stability in LCOTT-based microrobotic swarms. Through real-time feedback control and an elliptical-approximation algorithm, long-distance autonomous navigation of microrobotic swarms was achieved, including obstacle avoidance in constrained environments.
  3. Multicellular Organism Manipulation
    The project extended the optothermal manipulation platform to C. elegans, integrating laser-generated microbubbles with cooling systems to enable biocompatible manipulation. The Marangoni convection flow and surface tension of the bubbles facilitated dynamic chemotaxis assays, showcasing the system's potential for broader biological research with minimal damage to the nematodes.
Broader Impacts
The project's outcomes highlight transformative potential for optothermal manipulation across a wide range of fields. Applications span from precision drug delivery to autonomous microrobotics and fundamental biological studies, offering novel tools for biomedical, biophysical, and nanotechnological research. Furthermore, the project contributed to workforce development by training graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in cutting-edge optical manipulation technologies.
